intro: Gomphandra salicifolia, commonly known as the willow-leaved gomphandra, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, willow-like leaves. The plant produces small, white to greenish-yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in forest understories. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and taxonomic studies.
